description.text:
[EN]
To improve my audio experience on my Logitech Z906 surround sound set, I developed a kit to position my speakers higher. The base is made to fit on Ikea KALLAX furniture. The pipe to increase the height of the speakers is a 12.7mm-diameter curtain pipe bought at the local GAMMA (parts store / DIY store). The upper part, holding the speaker, is designed un such a way that the speaker faces straight ahead instead of slightly upwards, therefore having a descending side. At the back, a hole is made for a M6 bolt, which fits in the speaker for about 2-3mm before it's stuck. I also designed the parts in a way that allows the audio cables to go through the pipe. Feel free to remix it to your needs!

[NL]
Om de audioweergave ervaring van mijn Logitech Z906 speakers te verbeteren heb ik een set van 2 modellen gemaakt om de speakers hoger t.o.v. mijn tv te plaatsen. Ze zijn gemaakt om op een Ikea KALLAX kast te passen. De buis is een gordijnroede van de Gamma van 12.7mm doorsnee. De bovenkant, waar de speaker op leunt, heeft een schuin aflopende voet zodat de speaker rechtdoor wijst, in plaats van omhoog. Aan de achterkant is een gat voor een M6 bout, welke ongeveer 2-3mm in de speaker schroeft voor hij vast zit. Dit houdt hem op zijn plek. Er is bovendien mogelijkheid om de kabel door de buis te leiden, zodat die weggewerkt is. Voel je vrij om hem te remixen naar jouw maten.

A simple design for a composite adapter for the PC Engine (the one in the photo is an older version, without the logo, and the cylinders were too thin). In addition to this I used an old scart to composite adapter with the scart side desoldered (the markings on the bottom are in the proper place for the little circuit board on mine, they may or may not be right for yours. If they don't fit just use a hobby knife to remove them), some wire, and five female wire to pin connectors (the ones I got were called 2.54mm dupont jumper wire connectors).
Attach the connectors to the wires, and insert them into the proper holes (if you're directly facing the pc engine side of the adapter that's all the holes on the right, and hole two and three on the left).
Once that is done you can solder the wires to their proper places on the composite side:

Audio R= Top row, first pin from the right.
Audio L=Bottom row, first pin from the right.
Audio Ground= Top row, second pin from the right.
Video= Bottom row, second pin from the left.
Video Ground= Bottom row, third pin from the left.

Once that's done test it, and if everything works as it should (if the markings don't work for your circuit board use a dab of hot glue to keep the circuit board in place) you can wrap the excess wire around the cylinders (that's what they're there for after all) and glue the top into place. I used hot glue because it'll keep everything together, but it can easily be removed by a knife if I need to open it up again.

As the title says, this is a smaller version of my other thumb nut remix. It should clear the sides of the frame on a bed of a Prusa i3.

It has a simple design which preserves the top and edges of your desk, as it mounts to the underside! The 'Desk Mounted Headphone Holder' was designed to cater for a wide range of headphones with head bands up to 6cm (2.3 inches) in width. It is designed to print easily without supports, and requires minimal (if any) cleanup on the screw holes.

It sits flush against the edge of the desk creating a clean and unobtrusive look. It can easily be sanded and then painted to match the colour of your desk.

Edit - 30/10/17: I added a version to fit a 16mm thick desk top, as requested by user 'tgilles.'

Happy printing!

The 'Desk Mounted Headphone Holder' uses screws between 3 and 3.5mm in diameter. The screw holes are exactly 3.5mm in diameter, so feel free to use screws which you feel are appropriate.

I simply held the print in place, and used a pointed tool to indent the underside of the desk as a guide for my drill. I did very shallow pilot holes as the screws are somewhat self tapping.

The head of the screws will sit beneath the surface of the print, as the holes have a 7mm counter-bore.

From the bottom of the mounting arm to the top of the holder is about 27mm. The bottom of the mounting arm is what will be resting on the underside of the desk, and so this model will not be too appropriate for desks thinner than 27mm. The desk shown in the photos is the 'Linnmon' table top from Ikea which comes in at a width of 34mm.

Supports: Not needed

Layer Height: 0.15 (as seen in the pictures, can be printed at 0.2)

Print Orientation: Print this model as default, which should be with the front on the print bed.

Material: PLA or ABS (I used PLA for mine)

This is a simple thing I built to house my thermometer/hygrometer module so that it sits more comfortably on the desk.

The internal module is the type sold on Ebay.Aliexpress and is:
Size: 4.7cm x 2.7cm x 1.3cm/1.85" x 1.06"x 0.51" (Approx.)

This design works well, is quite a tight fit for the module and angles the display up to be easily read. The rear vents allow plenty of air access so the readings are not affected.

The case was printed as a single piece successfully with no support and no overhang issue. You may choose to add support if your printer will require it. On my first print I had slight curling of the corners, a 5mm brim fixed this for me.

Raspberry Pi racedash for the NA and NB Miata. I have made several of these now and this is the final revision for now.

The two frames are joined together and the center part which holds the screen.The Pi will slide into it, making it a somewhat modular solution. I have included two left frames. One with a 52mm hole for a fuel gauge and one without.

The electronics cover has a slot in it for a Adafruit UltimateGPS module as well as a hole for their GPS cable adapter.

I am working on a guide for this. It contains a part list for everything needed:

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1clyCtAOg4kK9ECIgbDkbVPlMhZW9lugoe9_KubAGJEQ

Update June 3:

Added NB version. Not tested in car, but the dimensions are right when compared to a spare NB cluster I have.
No ETA on the guide yet.

title: Post Stabilizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing is a post stabilizer that is meant to make the surface area of the metal post larger and easier to hit. It is recommended that you print at 100% density as the 20% one easily sheered at the stress line seen above. A cloth (an old cut up rag) is also recommended between any metal surfaces to prolong the life of this device and create a good guiding fit.

If you liked it please like and make.

author: sergiof_816

title: Prusa I3 Mk2 Y motor spacer

description.text: If you have Prusa i3 Mk2 and the Y axis movements are rough or noisy, check the Y motor position. When you look down on it, the motor should be parallel to the threaded rods. If it's not - the rear end of the motor is closer to the rods - that's because the Y motor holder has a weakness. The motor is mounted on one edge only (unlike the X motor that is mounted by 3 screws, Y motor only has two). The force exerted by the belt onto the pulley is off-axis and may bend the Y motor holder or even crack it (mine has a hairline crack in the corner below the Y endstop). The simplest solution to this problem, without taking apart the Y axis, is to add support to the rear end of the Y motor. This Y motor spacer clips onto the threaded rods and keeps the Y motor parallel to the rods. To install it, just insert a screwdriver between the motor and the rods and carefully push the motor away from the rods (don't pinch or cut the motor cables, and don't bend the Y holder in the other direction), then slide the spacer along the rods under the motor (not too far, the cable must not get pinched between the motor and the spacer) and let go of the motor, it will hold the spacer in place.

comments.author: baconinabun

comments.text: The kit I just built had this spacer included. The issue with the included spacer was that it needed to be drilled out to make sure the motor is not cocked. The included one from prusa forced the the front of the motor to right (there was a 1mm difference between the rear left and top left to left threaded rod.
comments.author: nuggyblake

comments.text: You're right, looks like they added it in Mk2S. It wasn't listed in the announcement as one of the changes, so I missed it. But the assembly manual for Mk2S has one extra part for the Y axis, they call it "Y motor distance". They made a cutout for the wires, so it can slide farther toward the motor (mine supports only the last few millimeters of the motor). Thanks for pointing it out, I wish they were more public with this weakness, something like an email to all buyers of Mk2 suggesting that they print and install the spacer.
comments.author: nuggyblake

comments.text: The spacer they included was badly printed. I had to ream out the cutouts a lot with a large drill bit. When I installed it it actually forced the motor out of parallel to the left threaded rod. It was approx 1.2mm jawed from rear left to left front of the motor. They introduced a solution that would have made it actually worse. I love my mk2s but it does suffer from "weakeness". Its odd really, it truly prints like a rolls royce but they use Lada parts for some of the more important parts. The front part fan has an issue with the screw mounts, the 2 screws for the extruder (push bearing against hobbed gear) is frankly hokey at best and plain dumb at worse for a printer of this quality. The Y bearing mounts and cable mounts need to improved. Its the best damn printer I have ever used and yet they go cheap with some of the parts and design. I guess Im ranting and in their defence its open source so you can improve it.

title: Linear bearing with 6mm airsoft bbs  for 8mm rod

description.text:
This is a linear bearing that works with 6mm airsoft bbs.
Print the stl, fill every hole with 3 bbs and then glue the cap in order to keep the bbs in place.

I've printed it in abs scaled up by 1% to prevent abs restriction and little error of printing, probably with good printer you can print in at natural dimension.

I've used normal plastic bbs and with some lubricant it works pretty good, probably it's better to use steel or ceramic bbs, I will try them as soon as possible.

NOTE: The external diameter is NOT the same as traditional 3d printer's linear bearing, it' exactly 23.32 mm.

I'm not anglophone so if you notice some errors in the text please leave a comment, thanks!

Printer:

HICTOP prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Notes:

For the first print I've made a rapid test with 0.8mm walls and 0 infill, it turned out to be enough strong to be used.

-fill every hole with 3 bbs
-glue the cap without drain glue down the holes
It's reccomended to lubricate the bearing.

author: SirioB

print_settings.Notes:: VASE MODE ONLY

title: Effector mounted blower duct for Delta 3KU

description.text:
Most designs for part cooling fans and blowers for Delta printers tend to reduce the available print area due to the chance of colliding with the printer columns or with the effector rods during printing. The intent of this design was to avoid this issue by "clinging" the design around the effector plate and careful consideration of all critical head positions to avoid collision. Another design consideration was to maximize the air flow by thickening the duct in one dimension where the other dimension is constrained.
This will print fast thanks to the fact it is done in vase mode to ensure the part is hollow. It is also very light.
Please let me know if you have any suggestions or comments.

Some absolutely critical things:

  • Print the main part (the duct) in Vase mode - configure this in your slicer (or you will end up with a useless filled duct)
  • Set number of layers for the bottom to 0 in your slicer or "no bottom" depending on the slicer.
  • Print the main part vertically (as the STL shows) with no supports (or you may end up with impossible to remove supports inside the duct)

Not so critical but advisable:

  • Print with your existing cooling fan turned on (the inclinations are not overly steep, but this will help with the surface finishing)
  • PLA or ABS -- it does not matter - I printed mine in PLA

Assembly:

  • Attach the snap fit bracket to the main part using 2 mm conical head wood/metal screws or superglue (but pay attention to the position if you are gluing - it needs to align with the holes)
  • Install the blower in the duct (use two 20mm long M3 screws and nuts)
  • Fit the assembly as tall as possible so it clears the bed by ~2mm when the nozzle touches the bed.
  • Depending on the position of your nozzle relative to the effector plate you may need to lower the hotend so that the base of the duct (the semi-circular piece that directs the air around the part) will not touch the bed. If this is too much work for you I have uploaded another version that will provide you with a lot more clearance (but less air direction).
  • Wrap the the bracket with a tie-wrap around the extruder heatsink (don't worry with heating the plastic - that area is cold). (look at the picture).
  • Optional design bonus: Use the square wholes on the top with tie-wraps to straighten the extruder wiring and filament tube.

Here is the blower I used (you will need one with exactly the same size)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B015S5XFJE/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Delta 3KU

No

No

Not critical

NOOOO

Notes:

VASE MODE ONLY

remixed_from.author: pieterbos82
remixed_from.title: The PrintBone: a fully printable playable trombone

title: The PrintBone v1.1: a fully printable playable trombone
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The PrintBone v1.1 is a fully printable trombone. It's been updated for easier printing and better looks with less need for support, better ergonomics and better fit between the parts. The sound and playability is the same and is still very good. Here only the bell, see the original PrintBone at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1845509 for a PVC slide.

For a recording both with a brass Bach 42B and the PrintBone bell, check https://soundcloud.com/pieter-bos-2013025 . This sounds an plays about on par with a regular brass trombone - actually it plays easier than most trombones.

It has an 8.5 inch bell and it fits a Bach 42 or Bach 50 slide connector, which is used on many other trombones, such as some Yamaha and Courtois trombones. So you can use it with a brass slide or a PVC slide. Or you can download the OpenSCAD sources and adapt it for any tubing you can find.

See https://github.com/pieterbos/PrintBone for the OpenSCAD sources. It's possible to create all kind of trombones with the OpenSCAD sources. The github link already lists a small bore trombone - it is also on the photo pictured here. I will release it later when I fixed some issues with it.

All parts are in the correct orientation for printing. You will need support for the bell and the bottom of the neckpipe. The other parts prints without support. Print with at least 25-30% infill, the pictured one has 40% infill and it gives a nice sturdiness to the bracing.

Find a print setting that has the least amount of leaks. After printing, check for leaks - apply soapy water, seal one end and blow through it. There should be no bubbles. Fix leaks with a thin layer of superglue.

After printing, you might need sand the tuning slide legs until they fit inside with the correct amount of friction. Use tuning slide grease.

Sand all the joints a bit. Glue the parts together. Happy playing!

comments.text: Why is the bell in two pieces?
comments.author: taxilian

comments.text: To make it fit the print bed of printers such as the prusa mk2, or ultimaker 2. Do you want a one piece version?
comments.author: taxilian

comments.text: That would be handy, yeah; I think I can put it back together in the slicer, but it's hard to do in a precise way.  I have two printers (Taz 5 and CR-10) that can print the bell in one piece
comments.author: pieterbos82

comments.text: I have added the one piece bell. You can also generate it from the openscad sources by setting bell_bottom_fits_on_plate=true .
comments.author: taxilian

comments.text: There is a scad file?
comments.author: pieterbos82

comments.text: There is certainly a scad file, or rather, several SCAD files. See https://github.com/pieterbos/PrintBone . Clone, then run the download_dependencies.sh script (or open in text editor and manually download in case of windows).

description.text: These shocks have been designed to be used on Mr. Crankyface's 3D printed truck.

Printer:

Geeetech I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

100

Notes:

Some additional material is needed in addition to printed parts.

  • 2.5 mm (diameter) Nails. They must be cutted at 26 mm lenght using a Dremel or something similar.

  • 1 pen spring for the rear shocks and 2 pen springs for the front shocks. Since the front part is heavier than the rear one, additional spring is needed to keep the body at the right height.

The parts "Cabeza_A" and "Cabeza_B" must be glued using cyanocrylate. The nail and the spring are introduced into the piece "Cuerpo" and then the glued parts are Threated into the piece "Cuerpo". Finally, "Anclaje" piece is also glued to the nail using cyanocrylate.

It has been tested in the forest in real conditions and is quite durable and efficient.

title: "Simplehuman 22 oz. Square Push Pump with Caddy" holder

description.text:
I started using the Simplehuman 22 oz. Square Push Pump with Caddy, Clear Soap Dispenser and found that it would easily slip way from the sink when I pushed on the pump. (Especially when it gets soapy.)

So to combat that, I created this! A tray to hold the caddy next to the sink and also help drain any extra soap or water straight into sink.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007IMB8S6/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Note: I printed this model by rotating it with the "sink lip" down on the bed (i.e. the tray is printed vertically).

This is listed as a work in progress as I test its durability over the next few months. So far its held up well under heavy use for a week.

Push fit LM8UU holder, similar to many others out there.
The difference is that the mounting holes are under the bearing itself rather than on tabs to allow it to be attached parallel to extrusions.

This is an easy to print Phone-to-Wall mount that I designed using Autodesk Inventor. The two piece wall mount is extremely simple and easy to print and use. It can be aligned or posed in any way you want.

The mount is also very universal, meaning that all mobile phones should fit in between the two parts (Apple or Android) There is also enough space in between the two pieces to allow charging while the phone is docked.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 or 0.2

Infill:

100%

How to Mount

Use 3M sticky double sided tape to mount it onto the wall. 3M ensures that you can place it very easily and not have it fall, while avoiding the usage of permanent glue.

What I would recommend when placing the mount onto the wall is placing the phone in line with the mount, and then sticking (or gluing) it onto the desired location.

description.text:
My version of a cooling fan + LEDring combination for my Geeetech Rostock 301.

IMPORTANT NOTE: REMOVE the alu piece between your nozzle and the cooling fan!
This will

  1. CLAMP your hotend much better
  2. bring your hotend a bit more down.
    If you don't, you run the risk that my cooler will not be 1mm away from your workpiece at all.

Ha, and of course: the fan that you can use is one of the three that you have in spare of the 3 extruder motors on top of your Rostock 301 ;)!

June 30: I wanted to update the fan to have a bit more airflow (see separate stl) and I just found out a major disadvantage of this fan :'( --> it limits the movement of the head! the rods bump into the top corners of the fan when moving to the 2 corners on your buildplate that are further away from the fan. In practise: no big prints with this fan :'( (So I didn't make any big prints evidently...) Overcome this a bit by keep bigger prints in the quadrant where your fan sits. Experiment a bit to know what I mean. Sorry folks!!
July 03: Uploaded a sketch of where you still can print with this fan mounted and where not. I'm pretty annoyed by this now that I found it out... But hey, the fan works very well on all my -smaller- prints i did so far

Printer:

Geeetech Rostock 301

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

-

Notes:

Print this thing without support. All is setup as bridges and where ever support is really needed I've added a single line wall that you can break and cut away easily.

To print it with support, you'll need to rotate the current .stl's

... in several steps.
A keen observer notices a difference in the pictures already. The main reason for making a new version was that the temperature of the nozzle made the PLA deform unevenly, causing it eventually to stick slightly to the nozzle. By adding some additional ribs that got solved.

Still ongoing: is this design good enough?
It is designed to stay above your workpiece 1mm. And the main assumption is: the plateau holding the nozzle is always parallel with the bed... but I fear that is not the case - or my printer is wrongly calibrated - in some locations the fan is touching the bed - and hence also my workpiece.
Looking forward to your feedback on that.

Update 4/17/17 - I have added a center beam for non-conductive plastic which removes the countersinks for the threaded inserts. I have also tweaked the conductive plastic design to slightly reduce the threaded insert countersink. I noticed some were loose after cleanup.

This was inspired by NA8E's morse code key http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:630117. I created this in Solidworks from scratch and went through 4-5 versions before settling (for the moment) on this one.

Similar to the NA8E key this one uses bearings and a precision fit shoulder bolt to support the main beam for smooth operation. This one uses all brass 4-40 hardware and brass inserts for the plastic to keep from stripping out or pulling out.

Another feature of this key is the center beam can be printed from conductive plastic to make connections to the top contact at the rear of the beam. It also has gap adjust and spring tension adjust.

The hardware necessary for this includes:
2 686-ZZ Bearings 13mm OD, 6mm ID, 5mm Thick
1 6mm dia x 45mm shoulder bolt
1 M5 x 0.8 nylon insert nut (McMaster 90576A104)
4 4-40 narrow brass hex nuts (McMaster 95130A110)
3 Screw to expand brass inserts for 4-40 (McMaster 92395A315)
1 4-40 round head brass 5/16" screw (McMaster 94070A107)
1 4-40 round head brass 5/8" screw (McMaster 94070A112)
2 4-40 round head brass 1" screw (McMaster 94070A115)

Check my personal site K5ABL.com for availability of printed keys, customized keys with call sign and hardware kits only.

Rostock

Printer:

Rostock MAX V2

Rafts:

No

Yes

.4mm nozzle, 0.2 or 0.25mm layer

Notes:

Base - 1.75mm PETG @ 260C
Beam - 1.75mm PETG @ 260C or ProtoPasta Conductive PLA @ 220C
35mm/sec print speed
support only on base - touching build plate only

Support will need to be removed under base.

Cross holes on base and beam for shoulder bolt will need to be cleaned up.

Recesses for bearings will need to be cleaned up. Bearings should be a firm press fit and run shoulder bolt through bearings before assembling to align bearings.

Inside of bearing supports and center beam where it contacts support will need to be filed/sanded just to smooth. Do not remove material or you will get some unwanted side play.

You will need to sacrifice a Pilot G-2 Pen or similar for its spring

Beam recesses for brass inserts need to be cleaned up only. Do not enlarge or inserts will not grip.
Designed in Solidworks 2012. Files provided in parasolid format for better portability

author: Han_Ne

description.text:
My son likes to play with the little toy cars and I thought, I'd build him a launcher for his cars.

I started with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1802809 but it didn't work out for me. I loved the simplicity so made a design with a similar mechanic.

It's a simple design, just 3 parts, some rubber bands and a cable binder. If you arrange the parts properly and use layer cooling, everything will print nicely without supports (PLA).

Originally I used a printed splint to keep the piston from shooting out. But the splint broke on the first try. So I went with the lazy option and fixed the rubber bands with cable ties.

Sorry for the bad pictures. I printed in black which is not the best color for pictures.

ASSEMBLY:
1) to make it easier, I suggest to hook up the rubber band(s) first.
2) insert the trigger
3) insert piston into the ramp (through the trigger, of course)
4) secure the rubber bands with a cable tie

To load the ramp:
I found it easiest to load the mechanism by turning the ramp upside down and push the piston in. Gravity will lock the trigger in place.

EDIT:
V2: I tweaked it a little. The piston is a bit longer and has small notches on the side to help keeping the cable tie in place. The upper latch on the ramp for holing the rubber bands is extended by 1mm to help hooking up the bands

EDIT 2017-07-12:
V3: made a slightly better design that is more stable and the rubber bands won't come loose as quickly

EDIT 2017-12-23
I made a new piston after torkel_b's idea. That way a cable tie is no longer needed.
Thank you for the suggestion!

EDIT 2017-12-31
New Version!
I added a Ramp that can be connected to a HotWheels track.
Also The mechanism was modified so the trigger will lock in automatically when the piston is pushed back.
And last but not least, the piston is a bit longer now... which makes cars go faster :-)

comments.text: Thanks for this it works just fine.However I would like to try a version with a hole for the rubberband instead of using a cable tie.

Hi,

I have Remixed this part using the original as inspiration.

I found that the original was too tight on the cheap V6 that I am using currently.

I also wanted to use a 40mm fan

the screws for the fan do not need nuts on the backside as I designed it so the corners of the main piece overlapped slightly, giving the screw some material to bite into.

I have retained the zip tie slots however I have found that These are not needed. The mount for the part cooler has also been dropped by 3mm as I found that it was sitting high on my machine.

NOTE please insert this onto the V6 from the bottom, it will not snap into place around it

Thanks

This is a Rhino data of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:225183 with its attachment.
multICard case is an IC card case which user can choose how to hold it.
By changing the attachment, you are able to hold your card case by "grabbing it", "putting fingers through it" or "hooking it". You can also create your own attachment, and enjoy a new touch to draw a card. The inner dimension of the case is based on Japanese PASMO standard, which is 85.7x54.1mm. Image video on Youtube:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Jvu7UinyyA&feature=youtu.be

First, make an Illustrator file using CAD. I used Rhinoceros and Illustrator for modeling/drawing. Next, cut it out using laser cutter. I used Epilog laser cutter, but any laser cutter should be fine as long as it can cut sheets bigger than 200mm by 200mm. I used 2mm acrylic sheet for the base part, and 4mm MDF for the attachment. Assemble it by looking at the 3D data(you need glues), and you are finished!

title: Samsung wireless charger holder for galaxy phones and gear S2

description.text:
My first design since getting my first 3D printer. Wanted something to keep my wireless charging pads for my Samsung S7 edge and my Gear S2 together. Not using stock samsung charger for the phone charging pad and therefore hole at the back for cable may be bigger than it needs to be or too small.

I plan to make some minor modifications to it, for example the bit sticking up at the front I would like it a little taller. Also I over sized the gear s2 charging pad hole/cut out so it's a loose fit as it's my first 3D printer and didn't know how much it would shrink when it cooled so this is another thing I plan to modify.

I printed in a no name transparent PLA as it's all I have atm as got it from a friend but plan to print this again at a higher res in black PLA material.

Geeetech I3 pro B

Had plans for it back before I had a 3D printer and initially I planned to have the cut outs in a simple rectangle shape though when I first modelled it in fusion 360 I realized that it would use too much plastic which would be wasted and would add to the print time. I therefore created the shape it is now.

title: Taper Attachment for Hardinge TL10 lathe

description.text:
This is all three parts for making a taper attachment for a Hardinge TL10 lathe. I made these models to make sure I had all the dimensions right!
The slider and slide bar match the stock Hardinge parts, and can be made from Ken's castings. The mount does not match either type of HLV castings, so I will be laying out DXF cutting files for the parts. The mount does not cover all of the machined mounting area; on my lathe I have a magnetic scale mounted on the top edge of this area. You may want to expand the mounting area if you don't have a scale.

Please keep in mind; these parts WILL NOT be strong enough for actual operation on a lathe!

author: Weldingrod1

description.text:
These Marble Run pieces are compatible with the commercial parts that have 24-mm inner diameter / 28-mm outer diameter.

There seems to be Marble Run play sets with different diameter than mine. Before you print check that parts are compatible with your existing play set.

I designed the female sockets with serrations. This made the Marble Run pieces much easier to 3D print consistently. I used different materials such as PLA/HIPS/ABS/T-Glaze mixed. You can twist the female/male joint to make the joint tighter or loose.

Before moving further use the test piece to check your print settings: marble_run_peruselementti_testipalikka.STL

title: Low-Poly Retro Link Remix w/ Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix* from Flowalistik on Youmagine.

I liked the low-poly design but I hated the eyes--those for the first thing I nixed. Next, I wanted to add a base. This was for a few reasons: I wanted to give a wider print surface to assist with adhesion for anyone wanting to print this out and I really, really wanted to use the Zelda emblem. I borrowed the base from here**.

After playing around with the design, I got this idea to remove the integrated rupee and add a separate one. If you have any green, blue, yellow, red, or silver (especially any translucent ones), print the rupee with that color. I shrunk the rupee down just a tad and it is a little smaller than the one that I removed but I did that to account for any possible variances in filament types and printer (mis)configurations. I printed mine in PLA but if you print in ABS, you might want to enlarge it just a little to account for shrinkage during cooling.

License: due to utilizing work from more than one author where the respective authors publish under different licenses, this work will contain the most restrictive license to ensure compliance. Any work that is derived from this design should maintain that level of restriction unless permissible by the original author.

*Original work belongs to Agustin Flowalistik
**Original work belongs to Anthony Djekic

Printer:

MonoPrice Maker Select v2.1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.12mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

If you use a translucent filament for the rupee, print it with no infill. It is really small so you shouldn't have any kind of problem.

Joining the rupee to the figure.

I first placed it in the spot to ensure there was a proper fit. Sand down and file away any rough edges if any exist.

I took an old soldering iron (not my nice primary one) and brought it up to heat. I then placed the end onto the bottom of the hand to melt the PLA just a little. I moved the soldering iron and placed the rupee into the hand. When the PLA cooled, it held the rupee in place.

If you don't have a soldering iron, glue or epoxy will work just fine. Just make sure you aren't going to melt half of your print by using the glue/epoxy--some filament types melt down around certain solvents and chemicals. Test on a scrap piece first.

comments.text:
Great enclosure! Thanks for sharing! Now printing a few.
One note though:
I see you made it for two 18650 cells to be connected in parallel. Do you use protected 18650 cells?
The thing is that this electronics board has protection circuitry only for one cell and using two unprotected cells simply in parallel could potentially be quite dangerous if you use unprotected ones. ( https://electronics.stackexchange.com/questions/198708/can-i-use-multiple-18650-batteries-in-parallel-with-a-standard-microusb-3-7v-cha )

description.text:
We needed a nipple spacer to protect sore nipples while breastfeeding, so I threw this together quickly in Tinkercad and added holes for ventilation. Keeps clothes, bras, and pads from squishing sensitive nipples.

Recommend using a soft, non-toxic, cleanable material like TPU - easily rinsed with soap and boiling water.

Wife approved!

Printer:

Hictop Prusa i3 Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

.3

8%

Notes:

Printed in soft TPU, .3 mm height for speed and scaled up in Cura (Mostly in Z) to fit.

I needed these quick, but you could probably print at lower layer heights for a smoother finish if needed.
Don't forget to finish the piece by taking off any sharp edges and fire-polishing the remainder for a smooth surface. Wash with soap before using.

description.text: Trapped ball toy.

Behold!! It's a blast from the past, Sonic from Sonic CD has finally arrived. Based off 3 different models he not only has his 2d sprite look but has 3d pixelated form, making him stand out even more. Sonic CD is my favorite sonic game due to it's element that the other 4 games don't have. If you want to add this character to your sonic collection, please download the file to custom print your own. If you have feedback, please reply to me in the comments. I hope you guys enjoy and like this print and the next upcoming projects.

Credits: To the creators of Sonic the Hedgehog Series, Spriters Resource, and their fans everywhere.

Notes: Oh boy, that project was stressful. I apologize if the outcome isn't as accurate but don't worry, I will make a better version in the summer. In the meantime look out for upcoming Projects and a new monthly series called 3d random sprites. Thank you

P.S. If you want to know the problem with this design, it is the spikes on the back on his head.

comments.text: I have auto leveling/tramming on my printer with an inductive probe and when I want a almost glass like appearance I adjust the probe offset and squish the first layer in so the lines completely disappear. This really only works with 0.3 layer height and sometimes 0.2 but not at all with 0.1 where it will just be too close and the extruder will start skipping steps. After the 1st layer everything goes back to the set layer height so once you get the 1st layer down you are home free.

description.text:
Edit 4/17/17: Added Version D which is able to be printed on printers with a more average build area. The spools don't sit as low on the shelf in this version and there is less clearance between the spools and wall (from 1 in clearance to 1/4 in clearance) to make the design more compact.

I've been accumulating more and more rolls of filament so I decided to make a wall mounted shelf to save space and stay organized. I didn't like the standard design where all spools sit on a rod because you have to take off half to get to the middle spool. My design uses two 1 inch diameter wooden dowels to support the filament so you can just grab the spool you need. I even added little tags to go over the dowels to label each group of filament. Please make sure to drill the shelves into studs and not just sheet rock.

Printer:

Prusa i3 Mk2

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I used PETG and a high infill but the design should be sufficiently over-engineered enough to even use PLA but PETG, ABS, or nylon would work best. This is meant to be used with 1 inch diameter wooden dowels.

Update: Mistake on my part, Body_2 now includes the ring for mounting the bearing. Not exactly sure how the first .stl did not include that.

This Spinny Cube was inspired off from a design I saw on Reddit. That spinner was still in production and I wanted to have it in my hands now.

Demo Video

The Body: The current body I have made is designed to use 608 Bearings. For printing, I left this flat on its side and used 50 Degree supports. This will require some cleaning to make smooth
The Caps: These caps were printed on their flat faces. Both caps are important to print. Each cap has a slightly different alignment between the helix connector in the center and the nubs on the outside. The caps should be almost flush in the cube when in place. A vice or press may be needed to press these into place, I plan on making a flat-to-cube-sided adaptor to make this easier.

Expect to do some sanding on the rounded faces to obtain the smoothest spin.

Printrbot

Printer:

Rafts:

30

remixed_from.author: alexan9er
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Power Supply 90mm Fan Case

title: Anet A8 Power Supply 80mm Fan Case with HEX holes

description.text:
I printed out a bunch of fan holders for 80mm fans for the Anet A8 power supply.

After printing about 4 different designs, and editing a much more, and printing them out with varying degrees of success,, this fan design
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2012944

made by
http://www.thingiverse.com/alexan9er/about

This did a good job of securing the fan through the use of zip ties on the power supply's mesh.

To attach this best, I took off the 2 power supply screws that hold the cover on, and then attached the housing to the mesh through the back.

I had 80mm fans that I wanted to use so I scaled the thing back to make them fit, and I attached the fans to the housing with computer fan screws I had left around.

I also edited it to have HEX holes to match the rest of the stuff I have printed.

I think that the A8 power supply should be less likely to blow up with a fan. After I added a fan the heat sink became noticeably cooler.

Here is a power supply cover that works with this holder
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2276593

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20+

Notes:

This should be printed hex mesh down, and you would probably get a more attractive finish if you printed it on glass.

author: gwarr42

title: Triple Expansion Marine Steam engine update 13

description.text:
Happy Easter !
Today as I enjoy the closing hours of my Easter weekend I am also uploading the final parts of this long project. Some of you have followed me over the past 4 months as I uploaded the over 100 part files. In reality this project has been underway for almost exactly a year. Last night I prepped the final files for publishing and printed the final Bill of materials. All total including every nut, bolt, washer, gasket and square key the final BOM has 164 separate and unique part files. The finished model as shown has an estimated weight 12,915 LBS. for those of you across the pond 5858 kilos. at this point I have no damn idea how many hours I have into it. This last new part update includes all the parts needed to complete the screw reverse portion of the model. I have also included the unfinished set of drawings that contain the completed bill of materials. The drawings are in the form of a PDF and are formatted in 11x17. The BOM has each and every part and the needed quantity that is on the completed model. As I am sure that excluding the hundreds of fasteners I missed a few parts along the way. If you are crazy enough to print this monster you may have to compare the what I have uploaded against the BOM. Of course, if anything you feel is missing please message me with the part name that you are missing and I will happily add it as one more update.

If this is your first time seeing this thing I suggest you look at all the previous updates to get the whole scope of the project. If you have been following me I give you many thanks for your support. And also, you may now return to your normal lives

This is a Rhino data of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:225183 with its attachment.
multICard case is an IC card case which user can choose how to hold it.
By changing the attachment, you are able to hold your card case by "grabbing it", "putting fingers through it" or "hooking it". You can also create your own attachment, and enjoy a new touch to draw a card. The inner dimension of the case is based on Japanese PASMO standard, which is 85.7x54.1mm. Image video on Youtube:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Jvu7UinyyA&feature=youtu.be

First, make an Illustrator file using CAD. I used Rhinoceros and Illustrator for modeling/drawing. Next, cut it out using laser cutter. I used Epilog laser cutter, but any laser cutter should be fine as long as it can cut sheets bigger than 200mm by 200mm. I used 2mm acrylic sheet for the base part, and 4mm MDF for the attachment. Assemble it by looking at the 3D data(you need glues), and you are finished!

description.text: Easter Egg decoration done with a modern twist on a Faberge egg design.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer or better

Notes:

Orient the egg straight up and use a large raft (25 mm offset) so the egg doesn't tip over when printing. At 0.2mm layer height or better, you don't need supports and the overhangs should be ok.

0.8 mm walls is enough, no infill needed.

3D Helix Sweep using Solidworks
  1. Revolved surface using outline sketch of egg shape
  2. Helix 3d sketch through center axis
  3. Swept a new surface using a line sketch on helix path
  4. Surface intersection sketch between egg surface and helical surface becomes helix path sketch wrapping around egg shape
  5. Swept a circular profile around new egg helix creating one 'weave'
  6. Circular pattern of 5 weaves around central axis

title: Digital Voltage Meter Holder for Hypercube and other 2020 frames

description.text:
This is a simple little box to hold a digital voltage meter to the 2020 extrusion. The voltage modules are available for about $1 from china. Here is a link to one, I have no financial interest in it.
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/New-Style-Mini-Yellow-LED-Digital-Voltmeter-Volt-Meter-Panel-3-3-30V/32777415211.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.AYuvuI

These just hook up to the power supply with 2 wires, positive and negative, nothing else needed. For me it is an easy way to monitor the power supply health and I think it looks cool. I run my power supply at 14.1 volts to heat the bed quicker.

The module is a press fit into the holder. If your machine is calibrated well, it will slide in with very light pressure and nothing else will be needed, although you could probably use a dab of hot melt glue if necessary.

Sketchup source is included. Enjoy!!!

description.text:
Old, slow, and inaccurate, my ancient Printrbot Plus is nonetheless my workhorse printer. While the cool, new machines are getting upgraded, the old PB just chugging. Why keep it? Because it's reliable, uses 3mm filament, and just keeps churning along.

This old Printrbot never had a cooling fan for the extruder. When it wasn't too much trouble, I'd aim a desk fan at it. Lately, though, I've been experimenting with firmware, and thought a fan would be worth adding. This is a basic fan in two iterations, one with the mount on the side and one with the mount centered. It requires a standard 40mm fan, (3) M3 nuts, (3) M3 screws, and a mounting hole drilled in the wood of the extruder. It's not much, but it may be of use to someone.

title: Table Clamp Swivel Joint for LCD Case

description.text:
So I really like the case that aaronroma made (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2067529) but I wanted the screen to be on the edge of the table. I used the free stand but it kept sliding everywhere so I designed a table clamp for it with a swivel for the LCD. The swivel does not allow the LCD to lie flat against the edge of the table, but it gives me some adjustments to see the screen whether I'm standing or sitting.

Materials:
4 - M5x10 bolts
2 - split washers
2 - washers
1 - M5 tap and corresponding drill bit if tap seems too tight (4 places)

It will clamp to the edge of the table if the table is ~22 mm thick or less. You'll need to tap the holes on the table mount for 4 M5 bolts (2 for the table and 2 for the display joint). I taped a couple pieces of tape to where the bolts would meet the table to prevent damage. To mount the display joint to the table mount, you'll need 2 M5 bolts, 2 split washers, and 2 washers. The split washer allows you to adjust the tension so that when you swivel the display, it stays in place. You'll need the normal washers to prevent the split washer from digging into the plastic and unscrewing your bolt.

title: Spyda 500 Quadcopter Accessory Pack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Various items that I have designed, collated or remixed during the build of my Spyda 500 Quadcopter.
This is a work in progress such is the compelling need to continually upgrade ;-)
  • Battery Mounting Board, for DeeJayEye and Crossfire arm plates
  • APM 2.5 Cable Tie Base (+ original lid).
  • GPS Mount Plate (for 3DR Telemetry TX and Crius GPS case).
  • AV TX Case (For a generic Audio Video Transmitter).
  • LC Power Filter Case.
  • An all in one AV TX Case which includes LC Power Filter slots and Minim OSD slots
    There are two GoPro mounts I have designed that fit straight on:
  • Here for the Super Simple Flexy Gimbal.
  • Here for a standard GoPro Hero 3 Mount and minimal case.
    http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
    http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

Print without support, it's all in the geometry!
  • Battery Mounting Board.
    • Creates a vertical mounting area at the rear of the Quad to make the CofG more central and to make room on the upper plate for the video TX module.
    • Attach to rear of quad utilising the 4 rear most screws of the rear arms. You may need to use longer screws than the stock DJI ones.
  • APM 2.5 Cable Tie Base (+ original lid).
    • Fit the APM 2.5 into the adapted lower case and screw down the upper lid. The upper lid that I have supplied here is exactly the same as the one contained within the original thing : 36883
    • The APM lower case has been modified to allow a cable tie mount to the Spyda top plate with a nice slab of vibration absorbing foam or silicon in between.
    • Tension the cable ties to compress the foam to adjust vibration dampening effect.
  • GPS Mount Plate.
    • Screw down onto top plate utilising the screw pattern of the front arms.
    • Print off the 3DR Radio case from thing : 148552 and super glue to this removable plate.
  • AV TX Case.
    • Cable tie the case through the slots in the Spyda's upper plate
    • Slide AV TX into case down the side wall slots. Push antenna thread through the receptacle in case.
    • Attach antenna to hold in place.
  • LC Power Filter Case.
    • Wire up the filter first then slide case over the top.
    • If wires exit the opposite end of the capacitor sticking out then you could cable tie the wires to the slots in the case if required.
    • I super glued this case (the red one) to the side of the AV TX case.
      I hope the pictures help more than my scribblings, but if there are any question then please comment below.

title: Back Frame brace for Anet A8 with better bearing clearence

description.text:
For my first printer I printed:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1430727
By Simhopp
http://www.thingiverse.com/Simhopp

It was awesome, but I had issues with the bearings on the bed hitting the top of the brace. Probably from using a printer that hadn't been calibrated, or the frame may have changed in the A8. So I hit the top of the brace with a heat gun and swished it down.

For my second printer, I thought Id make my life easier this time and just make a print that is pre-squished.

So this is 99% Simhopps thing, with a small change for bearing clearance.

author: GingerBrandon

print_settings.Notes:: At least 2 perimeters, no brim needed.  If you're cutting wine bottles adjust the size accordingly.  I've included the 123D Design file if you need to make any modifications since the glass cutter hole will obviously need to stay the same size while the rest of the pieces are enlarged.

description.text:
The glass cutter is Husky brand from Home Depot, about $2. Put a small amount of oil on the cutting wheel before starting. You can cut it dry but the oil makes the wheel last longer.

-Rotate the bottle in either direction applying slight downward pressure to the bottle so there is a clear line with no gaps all the way around the bottle. The line doesn't have to be deep.

-Next light a candle and hold the line on the bottle just above the flame and rotate until it's warm. Then, dip the bottle in a bucket or large cup of water up to the line.

-Repeat that until the bottle separates into 2 pieces, It will probably take several tries.

-You can use ice water to speed up the process, but there is a much higher chance the bottle will crack going up or down the side instead of along the line.

-After the bottle separates use wet sandpaper starting at 60-100 grit to smooth any jagged or sharp edges on the inside and outside of the rim.

-Once you knock down the high spots smooth it even further with 200-220 for a comfortable surface.

-Wash the glass thoroughly before using.

NOTE: I did use a rotary tool with a coarse drum sanding attachment to lightly hit some bad high spots, but if you do this WEAR EYE PROTECTION AND A FACEMASK / RESPIRATOR. Also use gloves and keep the rim of the glass moist to prevent glass dust getting into the air. You don't want to breathe that stuff or get it in your eyes.

Solidoodle

Printer:

Notes:

At least 2 perimeters, no brim needed. If you're cutting wine bottles adjust the size accordingly. I've included the 123D Design file if you need to make any modifications since the glass cutter hole will obviously need to stay the same size while the rest of the pieces are enlarged.

Drill holes in the tabs on the bottom of the jig and attach to any surface so that the bottom of the bottle you're cutting is flat against the back of the jig. If the glass cutter is a little loose in the jig a little epoxy will keep it from getting pushed out while rolling the bottle.

description.text:
The Retro Robot is a fun model perfect for your office or home. Whether the Retro Robot is inviting people into your office or terrorizing a LEGO city, it is a great addition to any collection. The Retro Robot is a ball jointed model so it can be put in almost any pose and is still easy to assemble, from separately printed parts.

The models pictured above were printed on my CraftBot+ at 75% (with the one tiny one at 25%) scale. The one on the right of the second picture was an early prototype that had larger ball joints. Due to the larger joints the model broke in several places while being assembled, and the design was changed to include smaller joints. The other one, on the left of the second picture, was the first of the redesign and went together smoothly.

Printer:

Craftbot+

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.200mm

Infill:

19%

Notes:

Be sure to print all the parts on their backs. Additionally, make sure to fully support the parts as necessary paying close attention to the pegs on the male ends of the ball joints.

I printed the models in the pictures above at a 75% scale and found that I needed to have a resolution of at least .200 mm so that the eye sockets would print properly. I also increased the layers to 5 because on several of the first prototypes there were holes in the exterior. I also tried to print it at 25% scale and it worked but is very fragile.

To assemble the pieces after printing align them as seen in the photos below. Googly eyes can be added for an extra bit of fun.

Joint Assembly Example: Step 1 Joint Assembly Example: Step 2 Joint Assembly Example: Step 3

description.text: .3mm first layer is OK since that is where the taper starts. Total pick thickness is .6mm. The Fusion 360 model has a sketch with name text in it that you can set. Try not to print letters/font combinations that have separate bodies in them. If you do and want to try that click modify drop down and combine before you save the stl so the mesh turns out well. The thicknesses can obviously be customized as well. This should be pretty much exactly a standard pick outline that I traced from a picture.

Duck Decoy

Search "wslab" for more designs.

I wanted a compact, low profile, camera adapter for my kayak. I modeled this up to based on Prestonf's Scotty male end adapter. It seems like it'll fit my needs perfectly.

Print this part with no support material. The main Scotty adapter has a sacrificial cylinder that allows a good print and breaks off easily. I printed this at 50% infill in ABS. I would not skimp on the infill since this could be subject to some shock which could cause it to break along a layer line and potentially result in a lost camera.

To put this together, you'll need two 1/4-20 bolts (1 inch long for the main bolt. I used the same size and just cut it down for the camera bolt, but I think 1/2 inch would fit), and two1/4-20 nylock nuts. The JPEG image shows the basic assembly.

The two cylinders that fit on top of the Scotty post will have to be stuck together after the nylock nuts are inserted into their recesses and the camera end bolt screwed up into place. I used acetone to "weld" them together securely. This produces a very strong bond that I have tested on various parts. The part fails before the weld does.

Insert the bolt through the bottom and tighten into place with a screwdriver. Tightening or loosening this screw will allow you to adjust the tension on the pan.

Attach a gopro tripod adapter and you will have pan and tilt. I purchased an aluminum one from Amazon. A little locktite will keep the camera adapter from coming off the bolt if you use the camera to turn the whole mount.

title: D-bot Print Carriage for E3D Titan Aero V6 + Ciicooler + BL Touch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
4/22/2017 Update! I have redesigned this to mount the Ciicooler from the rear carriage, and the BL Touch on the front left. This is better in almost every way! Now you only lose a little bit of X travel (about 15-20mm), can see the nozzle from the front, and the BL Touch is closer to the nozzle too. This requires a 20mm or shorter pancake stepper motor such as this one: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00PNEQ79Q

These updated files are only for the V6 heat block, but it would be pretty easy to modify for use with a Volcano, or you can use the original files (but the new design is way better).

Design goals:

  • Combine Bowden-like speeds with direct drive quality
  • Part cooling airflow that surrounds the print from all sides without totally blocking nozzle visibility
  • Support for auto bed leveling even on glass

In addition to the standard C/D-bot carriage hardware you will need:
E3D Titan Aero w/ E3D V6 heat block
20mm or shorter pancake stepper motor
Ciicooler: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2004629
50x50x15 blower fan
(2) M5 x 12-16mm screws and (2) M5 square nuts or regular nuts to mount the Ciicooler to the rear carriage
(1) M4 20mm screw and (1) M4 nut to mount the blower fan to the Ciicooler
Optional: BL Touch

Please let me know your results!

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

50%

title: Wristband Wheel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a robot wheel made to fit one of those "cause of the week" wrist bands, and generated with the Highly Configurable Wheel (One Wheel To Rule Them All) at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21486. Credit for the idea of using one of those wristbands (which I think was a fantastic idea and seems to provide excellent traction) goes to AUGuru. I just tweaked some of the settings and printed it. Unfortunately, I forgot to hit Ctrl-S before I closed down OpenSCAD after exporting the STL, so I don't know exactly what settings I used, but the wheel diameter measures 68mm and I used a 6-spoke diamond pattern with concavity and the "slots" option for tread. It was modeled for a 4mm motor shaft and a 3mm set screw. The print quality here is not very good, and I think I'll have to use an M2.5 because I can't drill out the set screw hole, but other than that the tire holds very well and the traction is excellent.

1) Print.
2) Stretch wristband around wheel as a tire.
3) Install on robot.
4) Run for your life because one-wheeled robots can be pretty mean. You can tweak the size and design by modifying the original OpenSCAD file. This one is quite rigid and string, using 3.38m of 3mm filament with 2 perimeters, 2 solid layers, and 20% honeycomb infill.

description.text:
A digital model of a raccoon skull from my personal collection I created using photogrammetry. I filled most of the major foramina with clay before photographing the skull. I did this to make modelling a bit easier and make it a little easier to 3D print. I left the infraorbital foramina open, but they closed up a bit when I built the model. On the right side the nerve, artery, and vein passed together through a single opening. It is still open in the model, although a bit constricted relative to the actual skull. On the left side the nerve, artery, and vein each had their own foramen. These foramina have closed in the model but are still visible as clearly discernable depressions. For the technically inclined, this provides a good example of why it can be dangerous to code the presence of more than one infraorbital foramen on a side as a character in phylogenetic analyses. For those less technically inclined, it’s super cool.

To print this skull, I’d cut each element into several pieces, in orientations designed to minimize the amount of necessary support. I’m presenting them as they are so that you will have the greatest amount of freedom using them in ways that fit your needs.

title: Arm Brace for MP Select Mini Extruder Arm

description.text:
This Arm brace's function is to reinforce the stock extruder arm on the MonoPrice Select Mini.

The idea is that the brace goes over the arm and then is pressed down.

Filament can be still be changed with the brace on, as there is a hole in the back for filament and the fitting of the brace is tight enough to allow pinching/squeezing of the arm to release filament.

Picture 1: Shows the TinkerCad image of the brace. Inside one can see it has a negative space of the extruder arm. The arm's shape was traced, scanned and then converted from a jpg to svg (http://image.online-convert.com/convert-to-svg) for upload to TinkerCad, expanded slightly for tolerance and removed from a block (actual multiple blocks).

Picture 2: Shows the printed arm brace. Again the shape is of the printer arm.

Picture 3: The stock arm. Funny, my arm didn't break at the bearing but did crack slightly at the tip when putting filament in (and is filled with baking soda and crazy glue). The fix isn't strong enough. But this final design is strong and tight fitting that one can pinch the extruder open to allow new filament. So this design has two properties: Stops the bearing/arm to break, and stops the tips from breaking (or allow it to be used with broken tip).

Picture 4: Brace just on top of the extruder arm. View point is the side the filament comes out of the extruder.

Picture 5: Same viewpoint as picture 4 but with the brace fully seated.

Picture 6: Top view of fully seated brace. Black on black but matches my printer.

I've used this brace and an early version at least since Sept 2016 and am still on my original feeder arm (but still have some arm backups ready to go)

MonoPrice Select Mini

title: Bike torch mount with quick release

description.text:
I wanted a torch mount with quick release for my 32mm handlebar, but found nothing I liked. The torch should be inexpensive, hold even I drive off-road and there should be no screws protrude to prevent injuries in case of a crash.
First tests are satisfactorily! I found a torch on Ebay for $12. It should have 1800 Lumen, I can'??t say if this is true - but it shines pretty bright and is worth the money. The torch is even bright enough that it can be used as a daytime running light. You will need the following tools/parts:
A small and middle file to smoothen the grooves.
A small screwdriver fits to your screws
A Dremel to remove the support
4 Tapping screws 3 x 10mm
4 Tapping screws 2.2 x 5.6mm (maybe this is something in inch?)

print_settings.Notes:: I have only printed this using PETG, in its current state it taps on the window a little bit. If you use a more brittle plastic it may break at high speeds.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Quality bearings are subjective. While you may not want cheap, oil or greaseless bearings for anything with a load, using them for a fidget spinner is ideal. Instead of spending money on super good bearings and then washing the grease out, why not add some clean wear on some cheaper ones?!

Just assemble the main peg with the bearing and cap screwed in and push the fan down onto the bearing. Take the whole mechanism to your car, roll down your window half way and slide the mount onto the back end of your window. Then, roll up the window to lock it in place and drive around!

After driving to work and back for 2 days (about 40 miles total) I had tripled my spin times!

I have noticed with the bearings I have been using that after some time in this fan apparatus, the balls seem to become more polished. I also tried using some toothpaste to see if I could get an even better spin. So far, I think clean and dry is better than using toothpaste or another hydrolyzed silica compound.

Wanhao

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Cable was shorting out, so I decided to fix it. Cut and soldered the cable back together and realized I needed something to keep it sturdy. Didn't care for anything already made on Thingiverse, so I decided to give it a go. Came up with this.

Edit: Added a version with a taller post. I feel like it gives the cable a little more support and now goes past the point of where I stripped the outside of the of the wire.

It definitely needs something to hold it in so it's not putting too much movement on the connections. I'm afraid if it wiggles too much, it may break loose.
